Xi Jinping:
Xi Jinping is a politician and leader of the Communist Party of China.  He was born on June 15, 1953 in Beijing, China.  His father, Xi Zhongxun, was a Communist revolutionary and former Vice Premier.  His mother, Qian Xinzhong, was a social worker. 

Xi Jinping joined the Communist Party of China at the age of 21 in 1974, during the Cultural Revolution.  He studied chemical engineering at Tsinghua University, where he graduated in 1979.  After his studies, Xi worked as the secretary of the Communist Party Committee in Hebei, a province in northern China. 

Over the following years, Xi Jinping held several leadership positions within the Communist Party of China.  He served as the Communist Party Secretary for the provinces of Fujian and Zhejiang, where he implemented economic reforms and was praised for his effective leadership. 

In 2007, Xi Jinping was appointed a member of the Standing Committee of the Politburo of the Communist Party of China, the highest decision-making body of the party.  This appointment made him the political heir apparent chosen by Hu Jintao, then General Secretary of the Communist Party of China. 

In 2012, Xi Jinping became General Secretary of the Communist Party of China, succeeding Hu Jintao.  He also assumed the position of Chairman of the Central Military Commission, thereby commanding the Chinese armed forces.  These appointments marked the beginning of his reign as China's top leader. 

Since taking office, Xi Jinping has launched a broad campaign against corruption in China, which has earned him considerable popularity.  He has also sought to strengthen the control of the Communist Party of China over all aspects of the country's political, social, and economic life. 

Xi Jinping was reelected for a second term as General Secretary of the Communist Party of China at the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party in 2017.  He has been hailed as one of the most powerful leaders in modern Chinese history. 

However, some of his policies, especially regarding human rights and freedom of expression, have been criticized by international human rights groups. 

Overall, Xi Jinping is recognized as an effective and determined leader who has played a key role in maintaining stability in China and in consolidating the power of the Communist Party of China.  His political legacy will continue to influence China's development in the years to come.
Narendra Modi:
Narendra Modi is an Indian politician, born on September 17, 1950 in Vadnagar, in the state of Gujarat, India.  He is currently the Prime Minister of India since May 2014, after serving as the Chief Minister of Gujarat from 2001 to 2014. 

Narendra Modi comes from a modest family.  His father, Damodardas Mulchand Modi, worked in an oil company and his mother, Heeraben Modi, was a homemaker.  Narendra Modi grew up in a simple environment but has always been passionate about politics and society. 

After completing his secondary education, Narendra Modi obtained a degree in political science from the University of Delhi in 1977.  He then joined the Hindu nationalist political party, Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS).  Modi held various roles within the organization, gaining valuable experience in politics and public affairs. 

In the 1980s, Narendra Modi joined the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), a prominent Hindu nationalist party in India.  He quickly rose through the ranks within the party and was elected as the national secretary of the BJP in 1995.  Through his charisma and leadership skills, Modi gained great popularity within the party and emerged as a prominent face of the BJP. 

In 2001, Narendra Modi was elected as the Chief Minister of the state of Gujarat.  His tenure as Chief Minister was praised for his economic development policies and investment in the state.  He successfully attracted many international and national companies to Gujarat, contributing to significant economic growth in the region.  However, his term was also marked by controversies, including the Gujarat riots in 2002, which resulted in the deaths of hundreds of people, mostly Muslims.  Modi faced criticism for his perceived inaction during these riots. 

Despite these controversies, Narendra Modi managed to consolidate his political position and become the undisputed leader of the BJP.  In 2014, the party won a sweeping victory in the general elections, leading to Modi being appointed as the Prime Minister of India. 

Since coming to power, Narendra Modi has pursued a policy of economic development and modernization of India.  He has implemented numerous economic and social reforms, including the introduction of the "Make in India" program to promote foreign investment and stimulate economic growth.  Modi has also launched initiatives to improve access to education, clean water, and electricity for all Indian citizens. 

However, his tenure has also been criticized for authoritarianism and controversial policies, particularly regarding human rights and religious minorities in India.  Some critics argue that Modi has favored a Hindu nationalist policy at the expense of other religious communities in the country. 

Despite controversies and criticisms, Narendra Modi remains a charismatic and popular political leader in India.  His popularity largely stems from his nationalist rhetoric and image as a man of action, which has attracted many voters in India.
Joko Widodo:
Joko Widodo, better known as Jokowi, is an Indonesian politician born on June 21, 1961 in Surakarta, Indonesia.  He is currently the seventh President of Indonesia, since October 20, 2014. 

Jokowi comes from a humble family, with his father being a rickshaw driver and his mother selling textiles.  Despite their difficult economic situation, his parents instilled in him values of hard work, honesty, and integrity.  These values shaped his vision and his political career. 

After graduating with a degree in economics from Gadjah Mada University in Yogyakarta, Jokowi started his career in the family furniture business.  He later founded his own furniture company, which became a great success.  His experience as an entrepreneur and his commitment to economic development led him to become more involved in politics. 

In 2005, Jokowi was elected Mayor of Surakarta, his hometown, and gained a reputation as the "people's mayor" thanks to his urban development initiatives and his close relationship with the residents.  His pragmatic and results-oriented policies captured public attention and earned him increasing popularity. 

In 2012, Jokowi was elected Governor of Jakarta, the Indonesian capital.  He continued to implement policies focusing on economic growth, improving infrastructure, and fighting corruption.  His reforms received much praise and led to significant improvements in the quality of life for the people of Jakarta. 

With his growing popularity, Jokowi ran for the 2014 presidential election and won by a landslide with 53% of the votes.  He thus became the first Indonesian President from a non-aristocratic background and without military experience.  Since taking office, he has launched numerous initiatives to promote economic development, education, health, and the environment.  He has also committed to strengthening Indonesia's regional and international alliances. 

Jokowi is known for his pragmatic governance style, simplicity, and closeness to the people.  He has succeeded in becoming a symbol of hope and change for many Indonesians who have been inspired by his journey, integrity, and determination. 

In conclusion, Joko Widodo, or Jokowi, is an Indonesian politician who has climbed the ranks from nothing.  His dedication to the economic and social development of Indonesia, as well as his people-centered governance style, have made him one of the most popular presidents in the country's history.
Mamnoon Hussain:
Mamnoon Hussain was born on December 23, 1940 in Agra, India.  He is a Pakistani politician and served as the 12th President of Pakistan from 2013 to 2018. 

Hussain comes from a business family and studied in Karachi, Pakistan.  He completed his degree in commerce from the M. A.  Jinnah Institute in 1963.  After his studies, he joined the family business and worked in the textile sector, becoming a successful businessman. 

Hussain started his political career by joining the Pakistan Muslim League (PML-N), the political party of Nawaz Sharif.  He was active within the party for many years and became an influential member of the PML-N.  He was also elected president of the Federation of Pakistan Chambers of Commerce and Industry. 

In 2007, after President Pervez Musharraf declared a state of emergency and suspended the Constitution, Hussain took part in protests against these measures.  He was arrested and put under house arrest for his involvement in the demonstrations. 

In 2013, Hussain was elected President of Pakistan following the PML-N's victory in the general elections.  During his term, he focused on issues such as improving relations with neighboring countries, Pakistan's economic development, and counter-terrorism efforts. 

However, Hussain's presidency was also marked by criticism regarding his largely ceremonial role and lack of real political influence.  His term was constrained by the powers of the Pakistani Prime Minister and Parliament. 

In 2018, Hussain stepped down from the presidency of Pakistan and was succeeded by Arif Alvi.  Since then, he has stayed out of active politics and withdrawn from public life. 

Mamnoon Hussain is married to Begum Mehmooda Mamnoon Hussain and the couple has three sons and a daughter.  He is known for his discreet attitude and loyalty to the PML-N.  Despite criticisms, he was respected for his integrity and sincerity throughout his political career.
Sheikh Hasina:
Sheikh Hasina Wazed, known as Sheikh Hasina, is a Bangladeshi politician born on September 28, 1947 in Tungipara, in the Gopalganj region.  She is the daughter of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, considered the founding father of Bangladesh, and has been the Prime Minister of the country since 1996. 

Sheikh Hasina belongs to the Awami League, a political party founded by her father in 1949.  Her father, Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, played a key role in the struggle for Bangladesh's independence from Pakistan in 1971.  Unfortunately, he and most members of his family were assassinated during a military coup in August 1975.  Sheikh Hasina is the only surviving member of her immediate family. 

After her father's death, Sheikh Hasina lived in exile in India for several years and returned to Bangladesh in 1981.  She quickly took leadership of the Awami League and began actively advocating for the restoration of democracy in the country. 

In 1996, Sheikh Hasina won the legislative elections and became the first female Prime Minister of Bangladesh.  Her government focused on economic development, education, health, and poverty alleviation.  She launched a number of social programs that benefited the country's most disadvantaged citizens. 

During her tenure, Sheikh Hasina faced many challenges, including terrorism and religious extremism.  She took firm measures to combat these issues and succeeded in significantly reducing militant activity in the country. 

Sheikh Hasina was reelected as Prime Minister in 2008, 2014, and 2018, and she is now in her fourth term.  She is widely recognized for her strong leadership, progressive vision, and commitment to sustainable development. 

In addition to her political work, Sheikh Hasina is also known for her commitment to human rights and gender equality.  She has been awarded numerous international prizes for her work, including the United Nations Human Development Award. 

Over the years, Sheikh Hasina has become one of the most influential female politicians in the region, and her leadership has been praised both nationally and internationally.  Her dedication to Bangladesh and its people is unwavering, and she continues to work tirelessly to create a stronger, more inclusive, and more prosperous country.
Shinzo Abe:
Shinzo Abe is a Japanese politician born on September 21, 1954 in Tokyo, Japan.  He is known for having served as Prime Minister of Japan twice, from 2006 to 2007 and from 2012 to 2020. 

Born into a family of politicians, Shinzo Abe was immersed in the world of politics from a young age.  His grandfather, Nobusuke Kishi, served as Prime Minister of Japan in the 1950s, and his father, Shintaro Abe, was also a significant political figure in the country.  This family influence played a crucial role in his decision to enter politics. 

After earning a degree in political science from the University of Tokyo, Shinzo Abe began his political career by working for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.  He was first elected to the House of Representatives in 1993, representing the Yamaguchi district. 

Over the years, Abe held several leadership positions within the Liberal Democratic Party, the main Japanese political party.  He served as the party's secretary-general and as Minister of Foreign Affairs. 

In 2006, Shinzo Abe was elected as Prime Minister of Japan, succeeding Junichiro Koizumi.  During his tenure, he implemented economic policies aimed at boosting growth and reforming the country's social security system.  However, his government faced numerous challenges, including a rise in unemployment rates and criticism regarding his handling of diplomatic issues. 

Shinzo Abe resigned from his position as Prime Minister in 2007 due to health reasons, but he returned to power in 2012 after his party's victory in the legislative elections.  During his second term, Abe continued to promote expansionary economic policies, known as "Abenomics," and also focused on national security and international relations. 

However, in August 2020, due to health issues, Shinzo Abe announced his resignation as Prime Minister.  He remained in office until the election of his successor, Yoshihide Suga. 

Throughout his political career, Shinzo Abe has been praised for his leadership and commitment to the stability and prosperity of Japan.  He has been recognized as one of the most influential leaders in the country and has played a significant role in strengthening ties with other countries, particularly the United States.
Benigno Aquino III:
Benigno Simeon "Noynoy" Cojuangco Aquino III was born on February 8, 1960, in Manila, Philippines.  He is the third child of Corazón Aquino and the illustrious opponent of Ferdinand Marcos's regime, Benigno Aquino Jr.  His family played a crucial role in the political history of his country, and he grew up with the deep conviction that democracy and justice are fundamental rights. 

After graduating from Ateneo de Manila University, Noynoy Aquino pursued further studies in the United States, where he obtained a master's degree in Economics from Georgetown University.  He then worked in the private sector for several years before deciding to dedicate himself to politics. 

In 1998, Aquino was elected as a representative of the second district of Tarlac, marking the beginning of a political career that would lead him to the presidency of the Philippines.  During his tenure as a representative, he was a staunch advocate for economic reforms and fighting corruption.  He was also an active member of the Finance Commission and contributed to the passage of several laws aimed at strengthening the country's economy. 

In 2010, after the death of his mother, Cory Aquino, an iconic figure in Philippine democracy, Noynoy Aquino ran for president and won by a landslide.  He took office with the promise to continue the fight against corruption, improve education, and strengthen the economy. 

During his six-year term, Aquino implemented several major reforms, including enhancing budget transparency, revising fiscal policies to encourage investments, and implementing social programs to improve access to education and healthcare.  He also continued to combat corruption by establishing special commissions to investigate alleged cases of corruption. 

While his term was praised by some for its economic achievements and anti-corruption efforts, Aquino was also criticized for the lack of progress in addressing deeply rooted social issues in the country.  Furthermore, some parts of the population felt he was not effective enough in dealing with natural disasters and security challenges faced by the Philippines during his term. 

At the end of his term in 2016, Aquino retired from political life and chose to live a more discreet life.  He passed away on June 24, 2021, from acute renal failure and cancer.  His legacy as the President of the Philippines will continue to be debated, but he will be remembered in history as a man who sought to build a better future for his country and promote democratic values.
Tr\u01b0\u01a1ng T\u1ea5n Sang:
Trương Tấn Sang is a Vietnamese politician, born on January 21, 1949 in Hanoi, Vietnam.  He was the President of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam from 2011 to 2016. 

Trương Tấn Sang grew up in a modest Vietnamese family.  He studied at the University of the Friendship of Peoples in Russia in Moscow, where he obtained a degree in economics in 1971.  Upon his return to Vietnam, he quickly rose through the ranks within the Vietnamese Communist Party. 

In the 1990s, Trương Tấn Sang held various positions within the Vietnamese government, specializing in economic issues.  He was Deputy Minister of Light Industry, then Deputy Minister of Industry before becoming Deputy Minister of Finance in 1997.  Thanks to his expertise and determination, he contributed to the modernization of the Vietnamese economy and its transformation into one of the most dynamic economies in the region. 

In 2006, Trương Tấn Sang was elected to the Central Committee of the Vietnamese Communist Party, which opened the way for him to increasingly higher positions within the party.  In 2011, he was elected President of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, succeeding Nguyễn Minh Triết. 

As President, Trương Tấn Sang played an important role in strengthening Vietnam's international relations.  He sought to diversify the country's economic partnerships and strengthen its ties with other countries in the region, including China, the United States, and the countries of the European Union.  He also worked towards promoting human rights and political reforms in Vietnam. 

Trương Tấn Sang retired from politics in 2016, after completing his term as President.  He continues to play an advisory role within the Vietnamese Communist Party and remains active in promoting Vietnam's economic and social development. 

Trương Tấn Sang is considered a pragmatic and visionary politician who has contributed to modernizing Vietnam and strengthening its influence on the international stage.
Recep Tayyip Erdo\u011fan:
Recep Tayyip Erdoğan is a Turkish politician born on February 26, 1954 in Istanbul, Turkey.  He is the son of a father of Georgian origin and a mother of Azerbaijani origin. 

Erdoğan grew up in a working-class neighborhood in Istanbul and attended a religious school where he studied Islam and theology.  He became interested in politics at an early age and quickly joined the Nationalist Movement, a conservative Turkish political party. 

He continued his studies at Istanbul's Marmara University, where he earned a degree in economics and business administration.  Later, he worked in the private sector as a sales manager for an international trading company. 

In 1994, Erdoğan was elected mayor of Istanbul, making him the first mayor of a major Turkish city from an Islamic party.  During his term, he implemented many reforms, particularly in infrastructure and social services, which earned him increasing popularity. 

However, in 1998, Erdoğan was sentenced to prison for incitement to violence and religious hatred following a controversial speech.  He spent four months behind bars before being released. 

In 2001, he co-founded the Justice and Development Party (AKP), a conservative and democratic political party that quickly gained popularity among the Turkish population.  Erdoğan was elected as a member of parliament and became the leader of the AKP in 2003. 

In 2003, during the legislative elections, the AKP scored a sweeping victory, allowing Erdoğan to become the Prime Minister of Turkey.  Throughout his successive terms, he implemented numerous reforms, especially in human rights, the economy, and foreign policy. 

Nevertheless, his rule was not without controversy.  Some critics accuse him of conducting an authoritarian policy and restricting individual freedoms in Turkey.  Western governments have also criticized his policy towards the media and ethnic minorities. 

Erdoğan was elected President of Turkey in 2014, with enhanced executive powers, thanks to a controversial constitutional reform.  Since then, he has continued to exert a major influence on Turkish politics, while sparking debates and criticisms. 

Recep Tayyip Erdoğan remains a central figure in Turkish politics, whose journey is marked by a meteoric rise and contrasting popularity.
Hassan Rouhani:
Hassan Rouhani is an Iranian politician born on November 12, 1948 in the city of Sorkheh, located in the province of Semnan in Iran.  He grew up in a modest family, with his father being a merchant and his mother a homemaker. 

Rouhani obtained his bachelor's degree in 1967 and then enrolled at the University of Tehran to study law.  He earned his PhD in law in 1972, which allowed him to become a professor at the university.  Alongside his academic activities, Rouhani also obtained a degree in theology. 

Rouhani's political career truly began after the Iranian Revolution in 1979.  He became a member of Parliament and quickly stood out as a pragmatic and moderate politician.  In 1989, he was elected as the Secretary of the Supreme National Security Council, where he played a crucial role in managing the war between Iran and Iraq. 

However, Rouhani's international recognition came with his appointment as President of the Islamic Republic of Iran in 2013.  He was seen as a moderate and pragmatic politician, with a stated willingness to restore Iran's international relations and advance negotiations on his country's nuclear program. 

During Rouhani's presidency, Iran reached the 2015 nuclear agreement with world powers, aimed at limiting Iran's nuclear program in exchange for lifting economic sanctions.  This was considered a major step towards normalizing Iran's relations with the international community. 

During his second presidential term, Rouhani also made efforts to reform the Iranian economy, particularly in addressing high inflation and unemployment.  He also advocated for freedom of expression and human rights in Iran, although some critics argue that progress in these areas has been limited. 

Rouhani's popularity fluctuated during his years in power, with some supporting his reform and opening efforts, while others criticized him for not being radical enough.  However, he is widely recognized as one of the most influential and important politicians in Iran, and his legacy in diplomacy and domestic politics will continue to impact the country's future.
Prayut Chan-o-cha:
Prayut Chan-o-cha is a Thai politician born on March 21, 1954 in the province of Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand.  He is known for having been one of the leaders of the military junta that seized power in Thailand in 2014 and for later being appointed as Prime Minister. 

Prayut joined the Royal Thai Army in 1972 and rose through the ranks to become a general in 2008.  During his military service, he received training abroad, including in the United States, where he obtained a master's degree in strategic studies. 

As a general, Prayut held several important positions within the Thai army, including that of Chief of Staff of the Royal Thai Army.  He was widely respected for his dedication and professionalism. 

In May 2014, Prayut orchestrated a military coup and seized power as the leader of the junta, the National Council for Peace and Order (NCPO).  He justified this power grab by citing political unrest and anti-government protests that had been shaking the country for months. 

Under Prayut's regime as the head of the junta, Thailand experienced a period of political repression and restrictions on civil liberties.  Political opponents were suppressed, the media was censored, and human rights were frequently violated. 

In 2019, Prayut was appointed as Prime Minister of Thailand by a Parliament dominated by the military.  His government faced many challenges, including managing floods, the Covid-19 pandemic, and economic issues. 

Despite the controversies surrounding his rule, Prayut also launched several significant political initiatives, including his "Thailand 4. 0" policy aimed at modernizing the Thai economy through investment in technology and innovation. 

Prayut Chan-o-cha's political career has been marked by ups and downs, but he remains a key figure in the Thai political scene.  His tenure as Prime Minister has been extended several times, and he continues to play an important role in Thai politics.
Thein Sein:
Thein Sein is a Burmese politician who was President of Myanmar from 2011 to 2016.  Born on April 20, 1945 in the Kyonku region, Thein Sein grew up in a modest family and received a limited education. 

After completing his secondary education, Thein Sein joined the Burmese army, known as the Tatmadaw.  He rose through the ranks and held several important positions within the army, including that of Commander of the Central Infantry Corps. 

Thein Sein made his first foray into politics in 2003 when he was appointed Prime Minister under the military regime.  He held this position until 2011 and was widely regarded as a competent and pragmatic technocrat.  During his tenure as Prime Minister, Thein Sein undertook progressive economic and political reforms to modernize the country. 

In 2011, Thein Sein was elected President of Myanmar in the country's first democratic elections since 1990.  During his presidency, he continued his efforts to reform Myanmar and bring it out of its international isolation.  He initiated a process of releasing political prisoners, relaxed restrictions on the media and bloggers, and initiated economic reforms aimed at attracting foreign investment. 

During his term, Thein Sein also worked to resolve the country's persistent ethnic conflicts and end intercommunal violence.  He engaged in peace talks with armed ethnic groups and signed several cease-fire agreements, although the results of these negotiations were mixed. 

In 2016, Thein Sein completed his term as president and handed over power to his successor, Htin Kyaw.  Despite criticisms against him, Thein Sein is generally considered a leader who played a key role in Myanmar's transition to a more open and inclusive democracy.  He continues to be an influential political actor in the country and has remained active after leaving the presidency.
Park Geun-hye:
Park Geun-hye was born on February 2, 1952 in Daegu, South Korea.  She is the daughter of former president Park Chung-hee, who ruled the country with an iron fist from 1961 to 1979. 

Influenced by her father from a young age, Park Geun-hye was groomed to become a politician.  She joined the Democratic Party of Korea in 1998 and was elected to the National Assembly the same year, representing the Dalseong constituency. 

In 2004, Park Geun-hye campaigned to become the party's candidate for the 2007 presidential election, but was ultimately defeated by Lee Myung-bak.  Nevertheless, she remained an influential figure within the party and continued to fight for her political ideals. 

In 2012, Park Geun-hye finally realized her dream of becoming the president of South Korea.  She won the presidential election with 51. 6% of the vote, becoming the first woman to hold this position in the country's history. 

During her presidential term, Park Geun-hye faced many challenges, including escalating tensions with North Korea and a struggling economy.  Despite this, she implemented various political and economic reforms aimed at modernizing the country and strengthening its position on the international stage. 

However, her term was marred by corruption scandals that began to emerge in 2016, involving her close friend Choi Soon-sil.  Media revelations about Choi's influence and her role in decision-making led to massive protests across the country, demanding Park Geun-hye's resignation. 

In March 2017, the Constitutional Court of South Korea removed Park Geun-hye from her presidential duties, stripping her of immunity.  She was subsequently arrested and charged with corruption, abuse of power, and coercion.  In April 2018, she was sentenced to 24 years in prison and fined 18 billion wons (approximately 16 million dollars) by a court in Seoul. 

Today, Park Geun-hye remains imprisoned and her political legacy is marked by corruption and manipulation scandals.  Her term has left an indelible mark on South Korean politics and has sparked a debate on abuse of power and corruption in the country.
Fuad Masum:
Fuad Masoum, born on January 1, 1938 in Koya, Iraq, is a Kurdish politician and former President of the Republic of Iraq. 

Masoum obtained a degree in law from the University of Baghdad in 1958, and then pursued his higher studies in Great Britain, obtaining a master's degree in political science from the University of Manchester.  During his time in Great Britain, he was involved in Kurdish political movements and was one of the founders of the National Union of Iraqi Students. 

Upon his return to Iraq, Masoum began his political career as a member of the Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP) in 1962.  He was elected a deputy from the province of Souran in 1974, but was forced to flee to Iran in 1975 due to the repression led by Saddam Hussein's regime. 

During his exile in Iran, Masoum became one of the leaders of the KDP and played a key role in the struggle for Kurdish rights in Iraq.  He actively participated in the establishment of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) in 1975, an influential Kurdish political party. 

In 1992, following the fall of Saddam Hussein during the first Gulf War, Masoum returned to Iraq and was elected President of the Parliament of the Kurdistan Region.  He also held the position of vice president of the KDP and played a major role in the reconciliation and cooperation between the KDP and the PUK. 

In 2014, Masoum was elected President of the Republic of Iraq, succeeding Jalal Talabani.  As President, he worked to promote unity and national cohesion in Iraq, especially in the context of sectarian violence and the threat posed by the Islamic State. 

Masoum is described as a moderate and respected politician who has worked to promote diversity and peaceful coexistence in Iraq.  He has also played a significant role in decentralizing power in Iraq and protecting the rights of minorities, especially Kurds. 

Fuad Masoum served as President of the Republic of Iraq until 2018, when he was succeeded by Barham Salih.  He has since stepped back from active politics but continues to participate in initiatives and political debates in Iraq and Kurdistan.
Ashraf Ghani:
Ashraf Ghani is an Afghan politician and economist, born on May 19, 1949 in Kabul, Afghanistan.  He served as the President of Afghanistan from September 2014 to August 2021. 

Ghani grew up in an influential Pashtun family and was educated in the country's top schools.  He later went abroad to study, earning a bachelor's degree in anthropology from the American University of Beirut and a Ph. D.  in cultural anthropology from Columbia University in the United States. 

After completing his studies, Ghani taught at the University of California, Berkeley, and Johns Hopkins University in the United States.  He also worked for the World Bank, holding several key positions as an economist. 

In 2001, after the fall of the Taliban regime in Afghanistan, Ghani returned to his country to work on reconstruction and development.  He was appointed as a special adviser to President Hamid Karzai and played a key role in establishing governmental institutions and the Afghan constitution. 

In 2009, Ghani attempted to run for the Afghan presidential election, but he finished fourth.  Nevertheless, this did not deter Ghani, who remained active in politics and continued to work on development projects in Afghanistan. 

In 2014, Ghani campaigned for the Afghan presidential election and topped the first round.  However, due to controversies surrounding the election results, a power-sharing agreement was reached between Ghani and his main rival, Abdullah Abdullah.  Ghani became president while Abdullah was appointed as the head of government. 

During his presidency, Ghani sought to promote stability and prosperity in Afghanistan.  He was committed to fighting corruption and strengthening governmental institutions.  He also tried to negotiate a peace agreement with the Taliban, but the talks were challenging and did not lead to a lasting settlement. 

In August 2021, following the rapid escalation of violence and the Taliban's takeover, Ghani left Afghanistan and sought refuge in the United Arab Emirates. 

Ashraf Ghani's biography is marked by his commitment to development and democracy in Afghanistan.  Although he has been criticized for his governance of the country and elections, he remains an important figure in Afghan politics.  His contribution to the reconstruction and governance of Afghanistan has earned him respect and recognition internationally.
Salman of Saudi Arabia:
Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud was born on December 31, 1935 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.  He is the son of King Abdulaziz bin Saud, the founder of the Saudi kingdom, and Hassa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi. 

Salman grew up in a powerful royal family and received a traditional education.  He studied Islamic law at King Saud University, where he graduated in 1954. 

In 1953, shortly before completing his degree, Salman was appointed deputy governor of Riyadh, marking the beginning of his public service.  He later held several key government positions, including Minister of Defense and Aviation from 1962 to 2011. 

On January 23, 2015, Salman became the King of Saudi Arabia following the death of his half-brother, King Abdullah.  As king, Salman has implemented a series of economic and social reforms aimed at modernizing the country.  He launched the Vision 2030 program, which aims to diversify the Saudi economy, reduce dependence on oil revenues, and promote the private sector. 

Salman has also taken steps to promote gender equality in Saudi Arabia, including allowing women to drive and granting them more rights in terms of work and education.  However, some of these reforms have been criticized for their slow pace and lack of real impact on the daily lives of Saudi women. 

Internationally, Salman has played a key role in Saudi Arabia's relations with other countries and international organizations.  He has also faced diplomatic challenges, such as the crisis in Yemen and rivalry with Iran. 

Salman is also known for his commitment to humanitarian aid.  Saudi Arabia has regularly provided financial and material assistance to countries affected by conflicts or natural disasters. 

Salman has married several women and has had many children.  His son, Mohammed bin Salman, was appointed Crown Prince in 2017, reflecting Salman's desire to plan a smooth transition of power. 

Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud is a leader who has sought to modernize Saudi Arabia while maintaining its central role in the region.  His legacy is marked by major reforms, but also by the complex challenges facing Saudi Arabia.
Islam Karimov:
Islam Karimov was born on January 30, 1938 in Samarkand, Uzbekistan.  He grew up in a modest but ambitious family and quickly showed an interest in politics. 

He studied economics at the prestigious Institute of Planning and Statistics in Tashkent, where he graduated in 1960.  After his studies, Karimov began his career in Uzbek economic planning, quickly rising through the ranks to become deputy minister of the economy in 1979. 

In 1989, Karimov was appointed as the first secretary of the Communist Party of the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic, which was then the highest political position in the republic.  He was later elected President of the Republic in 1991, when Uzbekistan declared its independence from the Soviet Union. 

During his reign, Karimov was criticized for his authoritarian rule, suppressing protests and restricting civil liberties.  However, he is also credited with maintaining stability and economic prosperity in Uzbekistan, focusing on developing the energy, agriculture, and tourism sectors. 

Karimov passed away on September 2, 2016, after being hospitalized following a brain hemorrhage.  He was buried in Samarkand, his hometown, where he rests alongside his ancestors.  Following his death, he was succeeded by Shavkat Mirziyoyev, who continued some of Karimov's policies while introducing more liberal reforms.
Najib Razak:
Najib Razak is a Malaysian politician who served as the Prime Minister of Malaysia from 2009 to 2018.  Born on July 23, 1953 in Kuala Lipis, in the state of Pahang in Malaysia, Najib is the eldest son of Abdul Razak Hussein, who himself was Prime Minister of Malaysia from 1970 to 1976. 

Najib received a political education from a young age, studying at St.  John's Institution in Kuala Lumpur before continuing his studies at the University of Nottingham in the United Kingdom, where he obtained a bachelor's degree in Economics. 

His political career began in 1976 when he was elected as the Member of Parliament for Pekan, a seat he held throughout his career.  He quickly rose through the ranks of the ruling party, the United Malays National Organization (UMNO), holding various positions within the government. 

In 2004, Najib was appointed Minister of Defence, a position he held until 2008.  During this period, he focused on promoting Malaysia's economic development by introducing policies aimed at boosting foreign investment and encouraging growth. 

In April 2009, Najib was sworn in as Prime Minister of Malaysia, succeeding Abdullah Ahmad Badawi.  He focused his tenure on implementing economic and social reforms, including promoting more transparent governance and introducing initiatives to attract foreign investments and foster economic growth.

Najib Razak's biography is marked by his years of service in the Malaysian government, but also by the corruption scandals that have tarnished his political career.  As his trial continues, he remains a controversial figure in Malaysian political history.
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi:
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi is a Yemeni politician born on September 1, 1945 in Abyan, Yemen.  He was the President of the Republic of Yemen from 2012 to 2021. 

Hadi began his political career by joining the Yemeni army in 1966.  He was trained at the Aden Military School and rose through the ranks to become a senior officer.  During his military career, he served in various positions, including as commander of the Yemeni armed forces. 

In 1994, Hadi became the Minister of Defense of South Yemen after the reunification of Yemen.  He was recognized for his military skills and security expertise.  In 2011, during the Yemeni revolution, Hadi was appointed vice president of the country by former president Ali Abdullah Saleh. 

However, the following year, after Saleh's resignation, Hadi was elected president in an early election held as part of the transition agreement that ended the political turmoil in Yemen.  Hadi took office in February 2012. 

As president, Hadi faced many challenges, including the rise of Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula and the Houthi movement, which had taken control of vast regions of the country. The ensuing civil war left the country devastated, with a major humanitarian crisis.  Hadi continued to lead the internationally recognized government throughout the conflict, but he was criticized for his handling of the crisis and for allegations of corruption and incompetence.

Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi's biography is therefore marked by his role as President of Yemen in a tumultuous period in the history of the country, with unprecedented political, security, and humanitarian challenges. Sushil Koirala:
Sushil Koirala was a Nepalese politician, born on August 12, 1939 in the village of Biratnagar, located in the eastern region of Nepal.  He came from a well-known Nepalese political family, the Koiralas, who played a major role in the country's political history.

Vladimir Putin:
Vladimir Putin was born on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad, in the Soviet Union, now known as Saint Petersburg, Russia.  He served as the President of the Russian Federation twice, from 2000 to 2008 and from 2012 to 2024, and also held the position of Prime Minister twice, from 1999 to 2000 and from 2008 to 2012. 

Putin grew up in a working-class family.  His father was a combatant in the Soviet navy during World War II, and his mother worked at a factory.  From a young age, he was interested in combat sports and started practicing judo.  He even became the Champion of Leningrad in this discipline. 

After graduating with a degree in law from Leningrad State University in 1975, Putin joined the intelligence service of the KGB, the Soviet security agency.  He was stationed in East Germany for several years, where he worked as a secret officer. 

After the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991, Putin returned to Russia and began his political career.  He initially worked in the office of the mayor of Saint Petersburg before being appointed Director of the FSB (Federal Security Service), the successor of the KGB. 

In 1999, Putin became Prime Minister under President Boris Yeltsin.  When Yeltsin resigned a few months later, Putin took his place and became interim president.  He was then elected president in 2000 and re-elected in 2004.  Faced with term limits, he was replaced by his Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev in 2008. He has also been involved in international conflicts, including the annexation of Crimea in 2014 and military support for separatists in Ukraine. Joachim Gauck:
Joachim Gauck, born on January 24, 1940 in Rostock, Germany, is a politician and former President of the Federal Republic of Germany.  He is known for his commitment to human rights and democracy. 

Gauck spent his childhood in the German Democratic Republic (GDR) and witnessed the injustices of the communist regime.  In 1945, his family fled the bombings of Rostock and settled in Sète, in the south of France.  They later returned to East Germany a few years later.

During the period of the peaceful revolution of 1989 in East Germany, Joachim Gauck played an important role as a spokesperson for the opposition group.  He was one of the initiators of the citizens' movement "New Forum," openly criticizing the GDR government and calling for democratic reforms.

David Cameron:

Fran\u00e7ois Hollande:

Mariano Rajoy:

Mark Rutte:

Charles Michel:

Milo\u0161 Zeman:

Prokopis Pavlopoulos:

Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa:

Stefan L\u00f6fven:
Stefan Löfven is a Swedish politician born on July 21, 1957 in Stockholm.  He is known for having been the Prime Minister of Sweden from 2014 to 2019 and from 2019 to 2021.

J\u00e1nos \u00c1der:
János Áder, born on May 9, 1959 in Csorna, Hungary, is a Hungarian politician and the President of Hungary since May 10, 2012.

Alexander Lukashenko:
Alexander Lukashenko is a Belarusian politician born on August 30, 1954 in the village of Kopys, in the Soviet Socialist Republic of Belarus (now Belarus).  He has been the President of the Republic of Belarus since 1994.

Heinz Fischer:

Simonetta Sommaruga:
Simonetta Sommaruga is a Swiss politician born on May 14, 1960 in Lugano, in the canton of Ticino.  She is a member of the Swiss Socialist Party and is known for being the first woman to hold the position of President of the Swiss Confederation in 2015 and 2020.

Rosen Plevneliev:

Muhammadu Buhari:
Muhammadu Buhari is a Nigerian politician born on December 17, 1942 in Daura, in the state of Katsina, Nigeria.  He is the current President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria, since May 29, 2015.

Hailemariam Desalegn:
Hailemariam Desalegn is an Ethiopian politician born on July 19, 1965 in Boloso Sore, in the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region in Ethiopia.

Abdel Fattah el-Sisi:
Abdel Fattah el-Sissi, born on November 19, 1954 in Cairo, is an Egyptian military officer and statesman.  He has been the President of Egypt since June 8, 2014.

Joseph Kabila:
Joseph Kabila Kabange was born on June 4, 1971 in Hewa Bora, in the province of South Kivu in the Democratic Republic of Congo.  He is the son of the famous Congolese politician, Laurent-Désiré Kabila, who was president of the DRC from 1997 until his assassination in 2001.

In 2001, Joseph Kabila became interim president after the assassination of his father.  In 2003, he was elected president of the Democratic Republic of Congo in the country's first free and democratic elections since independence in 1960.  He was subsequently reelected in 2006 and 2011. 

Joseph Kabila's presidency was marked by numerous challenges, including the civil war in Kivu and persistent insecurity in certain regions of the country. Jakaya Kikwete:
Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete is a Tanzanian statesman born on October 7, 1950 in Msoga, in the Pwani region, Tanzania.  He served as President of the United Republic of Tanzania from 2005 to 2015.

In 2005, Kikwete was elected President of the United Republic of Tanzania.  He succeeded Benjamin Mkapa and became the fourth president of Tanzania since independence in 1961.  During his presidential term, Kikwete focused his efforts on economic development, fighting poverty, and improving the lives of Tanzanians. 

Under his presidency, Tanzania experienced steady economic growth and attracted significant foreign investments.  Kikwete also launched several social development initiatives, such as building new infrastructure, improving access to education and healthcare, and promoting gender equality.

Jacob Zuma:
Jacob Gedleyihlekisa Zuma is a South African politician born on April 12, 1942 in Nkandla, in the province of KwaZulu-Natal.  He is particularly known for having been the president of South Africa from 2009 to 2018. 

Zuma grew up in a modest family and joined the anti-apartheid movement, the African National Congress (ANC), at a young age.  For several years, he was involved in resistance activities against the segregationist government, which led to him being imprisoned multiple times. 

After spending ten years in prison on Robben Island, Zuma returned in 1973 and joined the liberation movement.  He rose through the ranks within the ANC and held several important political positions, including that of ANC vice-president in 1997 and vice-president of South Africa in 1999. 

However, Zuma has also been involved in several controversies, including allegations of corruption and fraud.  In 2005, he was charged with corruption in a case related to an arms deal and was dismissed from his position as vice-president as a result.  The charges were dropped in 2009, shortly before the presidential elections. 

In April 2009, Zuma won the presidential elections and became the fourth president of South Africa since the end of apartheid.  During his tenure, he faced several challenges, including the global economic crisis, racial tensions, and demands from student movements. 

In 2018, following increasing pressure and accusations of widespread corruption, Zuma was forced to resign from the presidency.  He was replaced by Cyril Ramaphosa.  Since then, Zuma has been involved in several legal proceedings and remains a politically controversial figure in South Africa. 

Jacob Zuma's biography is marked by his role as a freedom fighter during apartheid, but also by allegations of corruption that have tarnished his political career.  His presidential term was both criticized and supported, but he remains an important figure in South Africa's political history.
Uhuru Kenyatta:
Uhuru Kenyatta, whose full name is Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta, is a Kenyan politician who became the fourth President of Kenya in April 2013.  He was born on October 26, 1961, in Nairobi, Kenya, and is the son of the country's first president, Jomo Kenyatta. 

Uhuru Kenyatta attended primary school at a local school in Nairobi, then continued his secondary education at St.  Mary's School in Nairobi and later at St.  Mary's School in Nairobi before obtaining his high school diploma from St.  Mary's School.  He then pursued his studies at the University of Nairobi, where he earned a Bachelor's degree in Economics and Political Science.

In 1997, Kenyatta was elected as the Member of Parliament for the Gatundu South constituency and was re-elected in 2002 and 2007.  During this time, he held several government positions, including Minister of Tourism and Wildlife, Minister of Finance, and Deputy Prime Minister of Kenya. 

In 2013, Kenyatta ran for the presidential election and won with 50. 07% of the votes.  However, his election was contested by the opposition, claiming there were irregularities in the electoral process.  Despite that, Kenyatta was sworn in as president in April 2013. 

As president, Kenyatta implemented various economic reforms to boost the country's growth.  He also fought against corruption and launched initiatives to improve access to healthcare, education, and clean water for rural populations. 

In 2017, Kenyatta was re-elected for a second term as president with 54. 27% of the votes.  However, his second term was marked by political tensions and opposition protests, questioning the legitimacy of his election.

Uhuru Kenyatta remains a key figure in Kenyan and African politics.  His political legacy is inseparable from that of his father, Jomo Kenyatta, and his leadership has played a crucial role in the transformation and modernization of Kenya.
Yoweri Museveni:
Yoweri Kaguta Museveni is a Ugandan statesman born on August 15, 1944 in the village of Ntungamo, located in western Uganda.  He is the sixth child in a family of ten children. 

Museveni spent much of his youth in western Uganda, where he was exposed to social and economic injustices that influenced his political ideas and vision for the country.  He studied at Mbarara High School and then at the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania. 

From a young age, Museveni was interested in African liberation movements and Marxist politics.  He was influenced by leaders such as Julius Nyerere of Tanzania and Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana, who advocated for African independence and socialism. 

In 1969, Museveni was one of the founding members of the National Resistance Movement (NRM) in Uganda, which aimed to overthrow the dictatorial government of Milton Obote.  Museveni played an active role in the struggle for democracy in Uganda and participated in several civil wars that rocked the country in the following years. 

In 1986, Museveni eventually succeeded in overthrowing Obote's regime and became the President of Uganda.  Since then, he has remained in power, being re-elected multiple times in controversial elections.  His longevity in power has been criticized, and some accuse him of suppressing political opposition and restricting civil liberties. 

During his reign, Museveni has been praised for his efforts to stabilize the country and promote economic development.  He has implemented policies that have fostered economic growth and investment in sectors such as agriculture, education, and infrastructure.  Uganda has made significant progress in reducing poverty and improving access to basic services under his presidency. 

However, Museveni has also faced criticism for his governance of the country, particularly regarding human rights and democracy.  Restrictions on press freedom and political opposition have been reported, as well as allegations of corruption and abuse of power. 

Despite the controversies surrounding his presidency, Yoweri Museveni is still regarded as an important figure in African politics.  His leadership has transformed Uganda into a more stable and prosperous nation, although the debate on the length of his tenure and democracy continues to divide the country.
Abdelaziz Bouteflika:
Abdelaziz Bouteflika is an Algerian statesman born on March 2, 1937 in Oujda, Morocco.  He is known for having been President of Algeria for nearly 20 years, from 1999 to 2019. 

Bouteflika comes from an Algerian family originally from Tlemcen.  He joined the Algerian nationalist movement at a young age and took part in the war of independence against France, which lasted from 1954 to 1962.  His active participation in the struggle for independence earned him the respect of his fellow citizens and shaped his political vision. 

After Algeria's independence, Bouteflika held several important political positions, including Minister of Youth and Sports in 1963, Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1963 to 1979, and Minister of State in charge of Foreign Affairs from 1981 to 1988. 

In 1989, Bouteflika was elected President of the United Nations General Assembly.  He became Minister of State and Prime Minister in 1999 and was elected President of the Republic a month later. 

During his tenure, Bouteflika implemented many economic and political reforms aimed at modernizing Algeria and combating corruption.  He also contributed to national reconciliation by granting amnesty to members of armed groups who had fought the government during the civil war of the 1990s. 

However, Bouteflika's presidency was marked by controversies and accusations of electoral fraud.  In 2019, as he was preparing to seek a fifth term, massive protests erupted across the country demanding his departure.  Ultimately, he announced his resignation on April 2, 2019, ending his nearly 20-year reign. 

Since his resignation, Bouteflika has maintained a low profile and withdrawn from active political life.  His fragile health has also kept him out of the spotlight.  He is often seen as a controversial figure in Algerian history, with some considering him a visionary politician, while others criticize him for his long tenure in power and the corruption allegations during his presidency.
Omar al-Bashir:
Omar al-Bashir is a Sudanese politician born on January 1, 1944 in the village of Hosh Bannaga near the city of Dongola, Sudan.  He is known for having held power for 30 years, from 1989 until his removal in 2019. 

Before entering politics, Omar al-Bashir joined the Sudanese army in 1960.  He then received military training in Egypt and returned to Sudan to pursue a promising military career.  Over the years, he rose through the ranks to become a high-ranking officer in the army.

Al-Bashir was also known for his support of radical Islamist groups and his implementation of Sharia law in Sudanese legislation.  This earned him support from some segments of the population, while others viewed him as a brutal dictator. 

In 2019, popular pressure against al-Bashir's regime reached a peak and he was finally ousted by a massive protest movement.  He was arrested and faced several charges, including corruption and war crimes. 

Omar al-Bashir's biography is marked by his long period in power and the controversies that have punctuated his rule.  Some view him as a dedicated patriot who worked for Sudan's stability, while others see him as a ruthless dictator.  His legacy is still subject to debate in Sudan and the international community.
Abdelilah Benkirane:
Abdelilah Benkirane is a Moroccan politician born on April 9, 1954 in Rabat.  He is known for having been the Secretary-General of the Justice and Development Party (PJD), the largest Islamist party in Morocco, from 2008 to 2018. 

Before entering politics, Benkirane obtained a degree in physics-chemistry from Mohammed V University in Rabat.  He then taught physical sciences in secondary schools before pursuing a career in the private sector. 

In 1994, Benkirane entered politics by joining the Justice and Development Party, which had been founded a few years earlier.  He quickly became an influential member of the party and was elected as a member of the House of Representatives in 1997.

In 2008, he was elected as the party's Secretary-General, succeeding Saadeddine Othmani.  Under his leadership, the party experienced significant growth and won the legislative elections in 2011. 

Benkirane became the Prime Minister of Morocco in January 2012, leading the first government led by an Islamist party in the country's history.  During his five-year term, he worked towards implementing economic and social reforms, although some of his policies were criticized by his opponents. 

In 2016, Benkirane once again led the PJD to victory in the legislative elections, but failed to form a government, leading to a political deadlock that lasted several months.  Eventually, in 2017, he was replaced by Saadeddine Othmani as head of the government. 

Since stepping down as Prime Minister, Benkirane remains active in Moroccan politics as a member of the PJD's National Council.  He continues to uphold the party's ideals and plays an important role in Moroccan political life. 

Beyond his political career, Benkirane is known for his straightforward style and ability to communicate effectively with Moroccan citizens.  He is considered a charismatic leader and has many supporters in Morocco. 

In conclusion, Abdelilah Benkirane is a Moroccan politician who has held important positions within the Justice and Development Party, including that of Prime Minister.  He is respected for his leadership and contribution to Moroccan politics.
Jos\u00e9 Eduardo dos Santos:
José Eduardo dos Santos was born on August 28, 1942 in Luanda, Angola.  He is the son of a father from Sao Tome and Principe and an Angolan mother.  From a young age, dos Santos showed a keen interest in politics and social engagement, influenced by the independence movements that were developing at the time. 

In 1961, he joined the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) to fight against the existing Portuguese colonial regime.  Dos Santos quickly distinguished himself with his determination and organizational skills, which led to his appointment as a member of the MPLA's central committee in 1962. 

After Angola's independence in 1975, dos Santos became vice president of the MPLA under Agostinho Neto's leadership.  However, shortly after, Neto passed away and dos Santos was elected as the party's president and the president of Angola in September 1979. 

During his tenure, dos Santos worked to stabilize the country after years of civil war and internal conflicts.  He initiated economic reforms aimed at modernizing the country and diversifying its economy, which was mainly based on oil.  His efforts to boost economic development were partly successful, transforming Angola into one of the wealthiest countries in Africa. 

However, dos Santos' presidency was also marked by criticism regarding the lack of transparency and democracy, as well as allegations of corruption and personal enrichment.  These criticisms intensified over the years, especially when he was reelected unopposed in 2012, after over 30 years in power. 

In 2017, dos Santos announced that he would not run for the next presidential elections, paving the way for a political transition in Angola.  His successor, João Lourenço, took office in September 2017. 

José Eduardo dos Santos remains a controversial figure in Angola's history, admired by some for his economic achievements and resilience in the face of challenges, while others criticize his management of power and the country's resources.
Filipe Nyusi:
Filipe Jacinto Nyusi is a Mozambican statesman, born on February 9, 1959 in Namau, in the province of Cabo Delgado, Mozambique.  He has been the President of the Republic of Mozambique since January 15, 2015. 

Filipe Nyusi grew up in a modest family, but he always had a passion for education.  After completing his primary and secondary studies, he obtained a scholarship to study mechanical engineering at the University of Mozambique. 

After graduating, Nyusi worked as an engineer in the Mozambican state company "Empresa Nacional de Hidrocarbonetos".  During his time at this company, he climbed the ranks to eventually become the CEO of the company in 2003. 

During his tenure as CEO, Nyusi played a key role in the development of the oil and gas industry in Mozambique.  Under his leadership, the country experienced significant growth in this sector, attracting many national and foreign investments. 

In 2005, Nyusi joined the FRELIMO party (Mozambique Liberation Front), which was the ruling party at the time.  He quickly climbed the party ranks and became a member of the central committee in 2007.  His political ascent did not stop there, as he was also appointed as Minister of Defense in 2008. 

As Minister of Defense, Nyusi worked to modernize the Mozambican armed forces and strengthen security in the country.  He was also involved in peace negotiations with the rebels of the Mozambique National Resistance (RENAMO), which led to the signing of a peace agreement in 2014. 

In recognition of his many contributions, Nyusi was chosen as the FRELIMO candidate for the 2014 presidential election.  He won the election and became the fifth President of Mozambique on January 15, 2015.

Filipe Nyusi is married and has two children.  Apart from politics, he is known for his love of sports and music.  He is also a member of the Rotary Club and several other philanthropic organizations.

John Mahama:
John Dramani Mahama is a Ghanaian politician born on November 29, 1958 in Damongo, in the northern region of Ghana.  He is known for having been the President of Ghana from 2012 to 2017.

Hery Rajaonarimampianina:
Hery Rajaonarimampianina is a Malagasy politician born on November 6, 1958 in Antsirabe, in the Vakinankaratra region of Madagascar.  He is known for having been the President of the Republic of Madagascar from 2014 to 2018.

Paul Biya:
Paul Biya is a Cameroonian statesman born on February 13, 1933 in Mvomeka'a, Cameroon.  He has been the second President of the Republic of Cameroon since November 6, 1982. 

Biya completed his primary education at the mixed public school of Nden and his secondary education at the Libermann College in Douala, and later at the Leclerc General High School in Yaoundé.  He then pursued his higher education in Paris, France, where he obtained a Bachelor's degree in public law and a Master's degree in international public law from the Faculty of Law at the University of Paris. 

After completing his studies, Biya returned to Cameroon in 1962 and joined the public administration as Deputy Chief of Staff at the Presidency.  In 1964, he was appointed Director of Administrative and Financial Affairs at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. 

In 1975, he was appointed Prime Minister by President Ahidjo.  When Ahidjo resigned in 1982, Biya succeeded him and became the second President of Cameroon.  He has been reelected several times since then, in 1984, 1988, 1992, 1997, 2004, 2011, and 2018. 

During his presidency, Biya has faced many challenges, including economic crisis, corruption, ethnic tensions, separatist movements in the English-speaking regions of the country, as well as issues related to social development and governance.

Alassane Ouattara:
Alassane Dramane Ouattara is an Ivorian politician born on January 1, 1942 in Dimbokro, Côte d'Ivoire.  He comes from a Muslim family of Dioula ethnicity. 

After obtaining his baccalauréat at the Blaise Pascal high school in Abidjan, Ouattara traveled abroad for studies.  He earned a Bachelor's degree in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania in the United States, and then a PhD in Economics from the University of Pennsylvania. 

In 1968, Ouattara joined the International Monetary Fund (IMF), where he held various positions for over twenty years.  He rose through the ranks and became the Deputy Director of the IMF’s African Department in 1984.  This allowed him to gain solid experience in the economic and financial field. 

In 1990, Ouattara decided to return to Côte d'Ivoire to pursue a career in politics.  He became the second-in-command of the Rally of the Republicans (RDR), an Ivorian opposition political party. In 2010, after numerous tumultuous elections in Côte d'Ivoire, Alassane Ouattara was finally elected President of the Republic, but the post-electoral crisis that ensued plunged the country into a chaotic situation.  Laurent Gbagbo, the former sitting President, refused to acknowledge Ouattara's victory.  A civil war broke out, and it was only in April 2011 that Gbagbo was finally arrested and transferred to the International Criminal Court to stand trial. 

Since then, Alassane Ouattara has implemented numerous economic reforms to revive the Ivorian economy and restore stability in the country.  He has also worked towards national reconciliation by establishing a Truth and Reconciliation Commission. 

Despite criticism of his governance and persistent political tensions, Alassane Ouattara was reelected President of the Republic in the 2015 and 2020 elections.  He announced that he would not run for a third term in 2020, thus ushering in a new political era for Côte d'Ivoire. 

Alassane Ouattara is married to Dominique Nouvian Ouattara, a French economist, and together they have two children. His biography reflects his remarkable journey in Ivorian politics and his dedication to the well-being of his country.
Mahamadou Issoufou:
Mahamadou Issoufou is a Nigerian politician, born on January 15, 1952 in Dandadji, in the Tahoua region, Niger.  He is known as one of the most influential figures in Nigerian politics and served as the President of Niger from 2011 to 2021. 

Issoufou began his political career as a member of the Nigerien political party National Movement for the Development of Society (MNSD-Nassara).  He quickly rose through the ranks of the party, holding various positions, including that of deputy secretary general.

Issoufou was also a proponent of regional stability and the fight against terrorism in the Sahel.  As Niger faced significant security challenges, Issoufou worked closely with other regional leaders to strengthen security cooperation and promote peace.

Mahamadou Issoufou's political career has been characterized by his dedication to the Nigerien people and his vision of a prosperous and peaceful Niger. Michel Kafando:
Michel Kafando is a politician from Burkina Faso, born on August 18, 1942 in Ouahigouya, in the north of the country.  He is known for his diplomatic career and his key role in the democratic transition in Burkina Faso. 

Kafando began his career in diplomacy by joining the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Burkina Faso in 1969.  He held various positions within the ministry, including that of ambassador to Ethiopia, Sudan, and the UN.  He also served as his country's permanent representative to the African Union.

Michel Kafando is respected for his wisdom, integrity, and dedication to democracy and human rights.  He has received several awards, including the Grand Cross of the National Order of Burkina Faso.

Ibrahim Boubacar Ke\u00efta:
Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, also known by the nickname IBK, is a Malian politician born on January 29, 1945 in Koutiala, in the Sikasso region, Mali.

Despite the difficulties faced during his presidency, Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta has left a lasting impact on Malian politics.  His commitment to stability, democracy, and economic development has left a lasting legacy, and he is still considered an important political figure in Mali.
Barack Obama:
Barack Hussein Obama II was born on August 4, 1961 in Honolulu, Hawaii.  From a mixed marriage, his father, Barack Obama Sr. , was from Kenya, while his mother, Stanley Ann Dunham, was a white American from Kansas. 

Inspired by his father, Barack Obama Sr. , who was an economist, Obama developed an early interest in political issues and social problems.  After years of traveling and studying around the world, he graduated from Columbia University in 1983, and then pursued his law studies at the prestigious Harvard University.

His career took a decisive turn in 1996, when he first ran for the Illinois State Senate, where he was elected, and then re-elected in 1998 and 2002.

In November 2008, Obama won the presidential election, becoming the first African-American president of the United States. 

Obama's presidential term was marked by several major accomplishments, including the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, reforming the healthcare system in the United States, reducing unemployment, reforming the financial system to prevent another economic crisis, and revising energy policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Dilma Rousseff:
Dilma Rousseff is a Brazilian politician born on December 14, 1947, in Belo Horizonte, in the state of Minas Gerais.  She comes from a family of Bulgarian origin and is the daughter of a communist immigrant. 

Dilma grew up in a politically engaged family, which strongly influenced her convictions from a young age.  She studied economics at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul, where she got involved in student movements and began actively fighting against the military dictatorship in Brazil at the time. 

Her involvement in political activism led to her being arrested and tortured during the dictatorship.  She remained in prison for nearly three years, where she endured numerous physical and psychological abuses.  However, this did not diminish her determination to fight for democracy and human rights in Brazil. 

After her release, Dilma continued her political commitment and was involved in the founding of the Workers' Party (PT), a left-wing political party.  She worked for the government of Porto Alegre, where she implemented a solidarity economy program aimed at reducing social inequalities. 

In 2002, Dilma was appointed Minister of Energy by President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.  She played a key role in implementing sustainable energy policies and promoting renewable energies in Brazil. 

In 2010, Dilma was elected President of Brazil, becoming the first woman to hold this position in the country's history.  Her first term was marked by measures to boost the Brazilian economy, reduce poverty and inequality, as well as promote education and women's rights. 

However, her second term was marked by controversies and economic crises.  Brazil experienced a severe recession, an increase in unemployment, and a major political crisis, notably linked to the corruption scandal of the oil company Petrobras. 

In 2016, Dilma Rousseff was impeached as President of Brazil following a decision by Congress.  She was replaced by her Vice President, Michel Temer. 

Since leaving the presidency, Dilma Rousseff continues to advocate for democracy and human rights in Brazil.  She remains an influential and respected political figure, despite the controversies surrounding her term. 

Dilma Rousseff remains one of the most important female politicians in the history of Brazil, and her legacy continues to influence and provoke debate in the country.
Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto:
Enrique Peña Nieto is a Mexican politician, born on July 20, 1966 in Atlacomulco, in the State of Mexico.  He is known for having been the President of Mexico from 2012 to 2018. 

Enrique Peña Nieto comes from a modest family.  He studied law at the Panamerican University of Mexico, where he obtained his degree in 1991.  He then continued his studies at the Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education, where he obtained a master's degree in public administration. 

His political career began in 1999 when he joined the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI).  He stood out for his charisma and ambition, which led him to hold various positions within the party. Peña Nieto implemented significant reforms in the fields of education, security, and poverty alleviation. During his presidency, Peña Nieto implemented economic reforms aimed at stimulating the country's growth, especially in the energy and telecommunications sectors.
